Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ultrahigh-Frame-Rate Compressively-Sensed Imaging using Ultrafast Lasers

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this program is to overcome the current limitations in ultrahigh-frame-rate optical imaging through the development of a photonic imaging architecture that incorporates the benefits of compressive sensing.

Intellectual Merit:
The intellectual merit is that current record-high frame-rate optical imaging architectures are severely burdened by the need to transfer and record massive amounts of information. This program will make transformative advancements to the state-of-the-art approach through the use of a photonic imaging architecture designed specifically for compressive sensing; building data compression directly into the measurement process. Thereby, this new architecture will enable high-speed image acquisition with a greatly reduced information capacity requirement as well as increased signal strength and will form a new generation of ultrahigh-frame-rate imaging systems for use in all areas of science and technology.

Broader Impact:
The broader impacts are that recent research into high-speed imaging suggests that the incorporation of ultrahigh-frame-rate imaging into flow cytometry will greatly increase the information extracted from the measurements. This is critical to applications such as identifying the presence of extremely rare disease-predicting cells within a largely healthy population. Such an application can have a broad impact on society through improved medical diagnostics and will be a focus of this research program. Additionally, the program will benefit the educational objectives of the PI through the development of hands-on laboratory activities for high school and undergraduate students, a new introductory undergraduate photonics course, and seminars and poster sessions for undergraduate and graduate students to gain experience disseminating their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this research program we developed numerous high-speed imaing systems. High-speed imaging has numerous applications but is challenged by the cost and performance constraints of the exisiting hardware systems. Through this program we developed several high-speed flow microscope systems for rapidly characterizing cells or particles flowing through a small channel. Such systems can be applied to imaing flow cytometry, which is a biomedical technology for characterizing the properties and health of a large population of cells. Our research was geared towards decreasing the cost, increasing the speed, and increasing the image quality of such systems. In addition through this research program we developed a high speed optical coherence tomography system. Optical coherence tomography is an imaging modality that allows for the capture of the three-dimensional structure of a small object and is largely applied to biomedical imaging. Our developed system was designed to increase the speed of such imaging systems allowing for a reduction in motion artifacts as well as novel applications outside of biomedical diagnostics. FInally, through this research program we also developed a high-speed LADAR system. LADAR or LIDAR systems are optical versions of RADAR and allow for the three-dimensional measurement of the surrounding environment with higher resolution than RADAR. Such systems are of great interest for autonomous vehicles such as self driving cars. Our research was geared towards decreasing the cost of a high-resolution for of LADAR known as FMCW LADAR. Beyond high speed imaging this research program also used similar imaging methods to develop extremely small imaging systems known as microendoscopes. Microendoscopes are fiber optic imagers that can be placed in hard to access areas with minimal associated tissue damage. Our research developed novel approaches to microendoscopy that allow for greater image quality for extremely small microendoscopes. Such systems can be applied to imaging the interior of the human body or for the study of the brain in freely moving animals.

Modified by: Mark Foster
